Input multiple feeds, add graphics, master audio, and stream in one robust, easy-to-use package. Studio Please download on a non-mobile device Download The Most Versatile Live Switcher Frame-accurate live switching and compositing, up to 4k Graphics, media, transitions and everything you need from a world-class production switcher. Log into Studio with your Vimeo account, and enable cloud simulcasting with Vimeo Premium. Use Studio on consumer-grade computers including the MacBook Pro with hardware acceleration. A new user experience mode designed for beginners or users with a simplified workflow. Invite anyone to join your live broadcast using a compatible browser and their webcam. Send participants a link generated from Studio and instantly see their live video over low latency WebRTC. Bring multiple Mevos into Studio as remote cameras over Wi-Fi or Ethernet. Edit with virtual multi-camera using the Mevo mobile app and see the result in your Studio multi-view. Import any popular media format, loop clips, make playlists, add recordings as clips in the list, and export clips as .mp4 files for easy sharing. Scrub your video to find the ideal moment, trim your clip with in/out points, and set clips to autoplay with your transitions. Control Studio from any Chrome browser on the internet, with Studio 'WebControl,' even on Android and Chromebook. Delegate graphics and stream management tasks to other team members in remote locations while you focus on cutting the show. End to end 4K multi-bitrate streaming with Livestream and YouTube. Create virtual cameras from any single camera input. Ideal for 4K inputs when streaming in 1080p or 720p. Eased camera moves, cuts, and presets supported. Easily control Pan Tilt Zoom (PTZ) cameras that support VISCA or NDI PTZ protocols, all from within Studio. Record your program in broadcast quality with, or without, overlays. Edit clips and air highlighted replays to your viewers without stopping the recording. Record up to four simultaneous videos in broadcast quality MJPEG to an AVI or MP4 file. Use Studio on your laptop! Studio requires significantly less processing power for computers with NVIDIA graphics cards that support NVENC, and/or QuickSync-enabled Intel processors. Studio software is free for all Livestream and Vimeo Premium subscribers (free trial available), or can be purchased unlocked for $799 (Windows only). Studio software comes pre-installed on all Studio hardware products. No subscription necessary. In other words, it’s worth an extra click! .itc-show-tooltip + .itc-right-tooltip-opener { display: block; padding-top: 5%; } View Cartrxedqtxvusfxvu Add to Wish List Item in Wish List Other Buying Options Used from $399.95 Email Print Overview Specs Quick Compare Reviews 17 Q&A Accessories rxedqtxvusfxvu to top Livestream Broadcaster Pro overview 1Description The Livestream Broadcaster Pro allows you to stream live from the field with nearly any HDMI camera. It takes your camera's HDMI output, encodes it as H.264 video, and streams up to 1080p over to the Livestream cloud service platform for viewing on mobile devices, any web browser, or a Roku-connected TVs. The Broadcaster Pro can be setup and fully controlled using the free Livestream app for iOS and Android devices. The app also allows your phone to function as a video monitor, letting you preview exactly what you're streaming. Alternatively, an OLED status display and front panel buttons allow you to operate the device directly. The HDMI port is standard-size, in many cases negating the need for an adapter. There is also a 3.5mm stereo audio input so that you can capture a secondary audio source along with, or in place of, the HDMI embedded audio. A headphone output is also included so you can monitor audio with confidence. For connection to the Internet, you are spoiled for choice. Where an access point is nearby, you can simply hard-wire the Broadcaster Pro with Ethernet. Alternatively, you can use 2.4 or 5 GHz Wi-Fi to connect to a wireless network. For use in the field, there is a USB port allowing you to connect a separately available 4G LTE modem, enabling true mobility. The Broadcaster Pro powers from an internal battery expected to last over 3 hours. Additionally, there is a power adapter included for chagrining or powering from a wall outlet. Livestream Platform A paid Livestream plan, available in premium or enterprise edition, is required to use this item. H.264-Encoded Live Streaming The Livestream Pro encodes H.264/AAC video at up to 1080p at 5 Mbps, and integrates seamlessly with Livestream's streaming service. Livestream's service is supported on a range of devices, including desktop computers, iOS and Android mobile devices, and Roku Flexible Internet Connectivity The Broadcaster Pro allows you to stream your content in three ways: Via 2.4 or 5 GHz Wi-Fi A hard-wired 10/100 Mbps Ethernet connection Using a 4G LTE USB modem (modem available separately) Mobile Device Operation Go live wirelessly and preview your stream via the free Livestream app for iOS and Android. Plus, even without a mobile device, you can still be in control using the joystick, selector button, and headphone jack directly on the Broadcaster Pro OLED Status Display A joystick on the device allows you to navigate the menu and change settings. The display shows various parameters, including stream duration, bitrate, and quality of Internet/network connection. A start/stop button makes it easy to begin or terminate a streaming session, and there is also a dedicated power and reset button Integrated Battery The built-in battery is estimated to provide over 3 hours of streaming. Additionally, an AC adapter is included for charging or powering where a wall outlet is available Supported Input Formats 1080i 720p 576p (NTSC) 480p (PAL) UPC: 853359004157 In the Box Livestream Broadcaster Pro Hot Shoe with 1/4"-20 Thumb Screw Ethernet Cable (1.25') PSU 18 W AC Adapter (6' Cable) Mini to Standard HDMI Cable (1.6') Modem Mounting Clip Limited 90-Day Warranty Table of Contents 1Description Livestream Broadcaster Pro specs Connectivity Inputs 1 x HDMI (full size) 1 x 3.5 mm stereo audio (mic or line level) Output 1 x 3.5 mm headphone jack Network 1 x RJ-45 Ethernet (10/100 Mbps) USB 1 x USB type A female for 4G LTE modem Wi-Fi 802.11 a/b/g/n 2.4 / 5 GHz 4G LTE Requires separately available USB modem Supported Formatsrxedqtxvusfxvu HDMI Input 1080i 720p 576p 480p Encoder Codec: H.264/AAC Quality: Up to 1080p at 5 Mbps Display Type OLED screen with joystick navigation buttons System Requirements Mobile App Requires Android or iOS mobile device for setup and control via free Livestream App General Battery Internal rechargeable Li-ion battery (provides over 3 hours live streaming) Power Requirements Device: 6 to 12 VDC Dimensions 4 x 3 x 1" / 10.2 x 7.6 x 2.5 cm Weight 5 oz / 141.8 g Packaging Info Package Weight 1.45 lb Box Dimensions (LxWxH) 6.6 x 6.5 x 3.6" Livestream Broadcaster Pro reviews Broadcaster Pro is rated 3.5 out of 5 by 17. Rated 4 out of 5 by Heraldo from Small item, Big solution We use the Broadcaster Pro to stream video of events like high school commencement ceremonies, parades, etc. Obviously, the stronger your internet signal is, the better/more reliable the feed will be. The menu is a little funky to navigate at first, but once you know where all of the items are placed it becomes easier. The one downside is that you have to pay a substantial monthly/annual fee if you would like to host the feed on a site other than the Livestream site. But, for the price of the device and the solution that it provides for streaming high quality video, it's definitely a step in the right direction. Date published: 2016-04-17 Rated 1 out of 5 by BC from Not for YouTube I thought I read somewhere that this can be used for YouTube live also but I guess I was mistaken. I called Livestream support to inquire about YouTube streaming but the unfriendly guy's brusque reply made it easy for me to look elsewhere. Returned and bought Teradec VidiU. Date published: 2015-08-04 Rated 4 out of 5 by BRM News from Great LITTLE box for live streaming I operate a local news website and want to offer live streams to the viewing public when big news breaks. In a small town that's usually a fire or the weather. I bought the Livestream Broadcaster Pro hoping to leave the laptop behind and truly go mobile. After a couple weeks of use it lives up to my hopes. Some what disappointing in the battery life. My first full charge lasted a little over an hour ( not the 3 hours stated)...which is about the same as my camera without plugging into an outlet, so it's kind of a draw on that. The Broadcaster Pro has the AC option which is a must for longer broadcast. One other thing I can note is once you turn the Broadcaster Pro on, it goes through a short setup, about 30 seconds, then when you try to connect to wireless, it does not recognize any until you turn off the device and back on again. Second time seems to be a winner, just a little time consuming. Have not tried the Ethernet port connection. I've been told it is better due to instability of wireless. But like I said, I want to be mobile and the Broadcaster Pro has allowed me to travel more lite and get the job done. Once It is streaming I have had no issues. Works great. Date published: 2015-05-29 Rated 4 out of 5 by Anonymous from good product this stream box is very easy to use. It sniffs out wireless and ethernet signals very easily. I little of a learning curve. But, if you follow directions and listen to the prompts from the red box, it streams rather well. If you have a slow upload speed, you may want to run the box on a lower quality. Test the different quality ranges on the box to see how the video reacts when viewing it on your computer. I did have a problem with one of these boxes a few years ago. But, the firmware was not up to date. The box does hook up to your phones wifi. This makes it pretty nice to stream live in the middle of nowhere. Date published: 2016-10-13 Rated 1 out of 5 by Anthony B. from You must pay extra on top of this to use Livestream Actually this box works great. And when you had the option to use the free plan with Livestream, even better. But now they require you have a paid subscription plan. So, I would go with Teradeck, since it's the same box essentially and has more flexibility. Date published: 2017-07-18 Rated 3 out of 5 by Anonymous from good but not easy to configure the configuration rely on the tiny joystick which is difficult to operate. also to start the streaming was not straight forward. Date published: 2015-08-27 Rated 5 out of 5 by webstreamer from Livestream Broadcaster Pro, the best of the best We bought 2 of those units and mix with the new BlackMagic Micro Studio 4K, its a very high quality product 100% recommend Date published: 2015-11-23 Rated 4 out of 5 by Meta from Old Version Streams Better Purchased this to upgrade my current Livestream Broadcaster. The new model streams in 1080, my older model streamed in 720p. The Broadcaster Pro is a far better and improved product, but if you don't have fast internet upload speed then its not going to stream well. I have 60 down and 10 up on my internet speed. You need about 10 up to stream smoothly in 720p with the older version Broadcaster. Unfortunately, the Broadcaster Pro needs a faster internet upload speed to smoothly stream in 1080p. So, I had to return it and go back to using my older Broadcaster, because it streams in 720p flawlessly, everytime. I would suspect you need an internet upload speed of at least 50 to have the Broadcaster Pro stream smoothly in 1080p. Keep this in mind before ordering and run a speed test on your internet service to see if your internet speed can handle the Broadcaster Pro. The allows you to stream live from the field with nearly any HDMI camera. It takes your camera's HDMI output, encodes it as H.264 video, and streams up to 1080p over to the Livestream cloud service platform for viewing on mobile devices, any web browser, or a Roku-connected TVs. The Broadcaster Pro can be setup and fully controlled using the free Livestream app for iOS and Android devices. The app also allows your phone to function as a video monitor, letting you preview exactly what you're streaming. Alternatively, an OLED status display and front panel buttons allow you to operate the device directly. The HDMI port is standard-size, in many cases negating the need for an adapter. There is also a 3.5mm stereo audio input so that you can capture a secondary audio source along with, or in place of, the HDMI embedded audio. A headphone output is also included so you can monitor audio with confidence. For connection to the Internet, you are spoiled for choice. Where an access point is nearby, you can simply hard-wire the Broadcaster Pro with Ethernet. Alternatively, you can use 2.4 or 5 GHz Wi-Fi to connect to a wireless network. For use in the field, there is a USB port allowing you to connect a separately available 4G LTE modem, enabling true mobility. The Broadcaster Pro powers from an internal battery expected to last over 3 hours. Additionally, there is a power adapter included for chagrining or powering from a wall outlet. Richard Baguley Gear Date of Publication: 10.09.14. 10.09.14 Time of Publication: 6:21 am. 6:21 am Three Camera Add-Ons That Let You Livestream Your HD VideoSub Title: Three Camera Add-Ons That Let You Livestream Your HD Video Josh Valcarcel/WIRED If everybody truly does get 15 minutes of fame, it’s best to make sure that it’s streamed live on the web. That’s the purpose of these devices: plug in a camcorder or camera, hit a button and you are live on the Internet. It could be a school play you’re broadcasting to grandparents abroad, a concert friends can’t attend, or a street-level view of a political protest. Of course, you can use a smartphone and one of a handful of apps to broadcast a video stream, but these dedicated devices let you it at a much higher quality. Foremost, you’re not limited by your phone’s camera; you can use a DSLR, a camcorder, or a compact camera with a special lens. Also, given the ability to fine-tune variables like bitrate and compression, you get more control over the file output. Best of all, with one of these small boxes, you don’t have to fiddle with software or arcane commands. Each device makes it painless, converting the video into an H.264 stream and sending it out over a Wi-Fi or 4G connection. Interested viewers can watch your broadcast either on the video services run by the companies who make the boxes, or in some cases, supported third-party services like YouTube. We looked at three of these devices: the $695 VidiU and the $1,590 Cube 255, both from Teradek, and the $495 Livestream Broadcaster. All of these devices are about the size of a cigarette pack, but the Cube has two external Wi-Fi antennas. The streamer boxes are designed to fit on top of a camera or camcorder, and include clips to attach to a standard flash shoe or tripod socket. They then connect to the Internet over a built-in Ethernet cable socket or 802.11b/g/n Wi-Fi networks (the VidiU and Cube also support the faster and less-crowded 802.11a standard). All three devices also have USB ports that work with a selection of 4G USB modems for the ultimate streaming setup: one that is portable and works anywhere with Wi-Fi or cell network coverage. Have HDMI, Will Stream The three devices are similar when it comes to ease of use, with all offering a small display and simple buttons. You can control the device completely using these hardware buttons, but the easier option is to use each device’s web browser interface, especially when it comes to things like typing in passwords. Josh Valcarcel/WIRED All three devices also offer you plenty of control over the resolution and bandwidth of the video and audio. They also offer bandwidth tests that will recommend settings based on the speed of your connection. In my tests with a fast home connection, I had no problems streaming HD video to YouTube and Livestream.com over a fast home connection, but I did find that when using a 4G connection, I had to throttle the bandwidth down to get a reliable connection. But even given lower bandwidth, all three devices produced sharp, clear video in my tests. It was here the external antennas of the Cube proved to be an advantage: the device did a better job of keeping a Wi-Fi connection at a further distance from the router. This is an important factor if you’re building a roving camera setup, or sending video a long distance. Remote Controls Both Teradek and Livestream offer apps for controlling these devices from a phone or tablet. Livestream’s app (for iOS and Android) allows you to control the Broadcaster remotely, as well as broadcasting video from your device. The TeraCentral app (iOS) allows you to view video from, and control multiple VidiU and Cube devices, but not to broadcast from your iDevice. Teradek does offer an Android viewing app (TeraView, Android 4.2 or above), but this can’t control Teraview’s products. It’s just for monitoring. The main limitation of these devices is battery life. All three devices include batteries (internal Li-Ion for the Cube and VidiU, three AAs for the Broadcaster), but can only run for short periods on battery power. The Cube managed to keep a connection going for just over an hour and a half, while the VidiU last about an hour and 15 minutes. The Broadcaster managed an impressive 2 hours and 23 minutes when streaming over Wi-Fi with a set of EverReady Advanced Lithium disposable batteries. The device doesn’t officially support rechargeable batteries, but they worked. Your mileage may vary, though, especially if using a 4G USB modem that has to be powered by the device itself. All of the devices allow you to extend this battery life by using an external power source, which can range from 6 to 12V for the VidiU, 6-18V for the Broadcaster and 6 to 28V for the Cube. That instantly makes them compatible with a wide range of external batteries designed to power camcorders and other devices. In addition, the Cube can be powered over USB, so you can use a USB battery pack to extend its battery life. Josh Valcarcel/WIRED The Broadcaster is the cheapest of these devices, but that’s because it is tied in with the Livestream service: it won’t work with other video streaming services. The VidiU and Cube will work with Livestream, YouTube Live, UStream and any other service that supports the RTMP streaming protocol. The Cube also adds support for the alternative MPEG-TS video codec and point-to-point systems, where you integrate the device into a larger video setup such as a NewTek Tricaster switching system. The Cube also allows you to view the live video on an iOS device on the same network, so you can preview the video as it is transmitted. The Broadcaster integrates with the companies own Livestream Studio software system, but not with other video systems. Our Pick If you use the Livestream service (or don’t mind having that as your only option) the Broadcaster is a great pick. It’s simple to use, performs well and integrates well with the other services that Livestream offers, like support for broadcasting from Google Glass. But it is limited: you are locked into Livestream. Your viewers will have a possibly unfamiliar web address to remember instead of good old YouTube, UStream and the like. The VidiU offers the same features, but with wider video streaming service support including YouTube, UStream and the RTSP protocol used by most other services. Most users won’t need the extra features of the Cube (such as the support for 1080p and higher bit rate video) so the VidiU is our pick for those who want to pick up a camera, plug in and broadcast a live event to YouTube or other streaming video services over Wi-Fi. If you roam further afield, the bigger antennas and wider range of bandwidth controls might make the Cube worth the extra cost. Some very big places have som… If everybody truly does get 15 minutes of fame, it’s best to make sure that it’s streamed live on the web. That’s the purpose of these devices: plug in a camcorder or camera, hit a button and you are live on the Internet. It could be a school play you’re broadcasting to grandparents abroad, a concert friends can’t attend, or a street-level view of a political protest. Of course, you can use a smartphone and one of a handful of apps to broadcast a video stream, but these dedicated devices let you it at a much higher quality. Foremost, you’re not limited by your phone’s camera; you can use a DSLR, a camcorder, or a compact camera with a special lens. Also, given the ability to fine-tune variables like bitrate and compression, you get more control over the file output. Best of all, with one of these small boxes, you don’t have to fiddle with software or arcane commands. Each device makes it painless, converting the video into an H.264 stream and sending it out over a Wi-Fi or 4G connection. Interested viewers can watch your broadcast either on the video services run by the companies who make the boxes, or in some cases, supported third-party services like YouTube. We looked at three of these devices: the $695 and the $1,590 , both from , and the $495 . All of these devices are about the size of a cigarette pack, but the Cube has two external Wi-Fi antennas. The streamer boxes are designed to fit on top of a camera or camcorder, and include clips to attach to a standard flash shoe or tripod socket. They then connect to the Internet over a built-in Ethernet cable socket or 802.11b/g/n Wi-Fi networks (the VidiU and Cube also support the faster and less-crowded 802.11a standard). All three devices also have USB ports that work with a selection of 4G USB modems for the ultimate streaming setup: one that is portable and works anywhere with Wi-Fi or cell network coverage. The three devices are similar when it comes to ease of use, with all offering a small display and simple buttons. You can control the device completely using these hardware buttons, but the easier option is to use each device’s web browser interface, especially when it comes to things like typing in passwords. All three devices also offer you plenty of control over the resolution and bandwidth of the video and audio. They also offer bandwidth tests that will recommend settings based on the speed of your connection. In my tests with a fast home connection, I had no problems streaming HD video to YouTube and Livestream.com over a fast home connection, but I did find that when using a 4G connection, I had to throttle the bandwidth down to get a reliable connection. But even given lower bandwidth, all three devices produced sharp, clear video in my tests. It was here the external antennas of the Cube proved to be an advantage: the device did a better job of keeping a Wi-Fi connection at a further distance from the router. This is an important factor if you’re building a roving camera setup, or sending video a long distance. Both Teradek and Livestream offer apps for controlling these devices from a phone or tablet. Livestream’s app (for iOS and Android) allows you to control the Broadcaster remotely, as well as broadcasting video from your device. The TeraCentral app (iOS) allows you to view video from, and control multiple VidiU and Cube devices, but not to broadcast from your iDevice. Teradek does offer an Android viewing app (TeraView, Android 4.2 or above), but this can’t control Teraview’s products. It’s just for monitoring. The main limitation of these devices is battery life. All three devices include batteries (internal Li-Ion for the Cube and VidiU, three AAs for the Broadcaster), but can only run for short periods on battery power. The Cube managed to keep a connection going for just over an hour and a half, while the VidiU last about an hour and 15 minutes. The Broadcaster managed an impressive 2 hours and 23 minutes when streaming over Wi-Fi with a set of EverReady Advanced Lithium disposable batteries. The device doesn’t officially support rechargeable batteries, but they worked. Your mileage may vary, though, especially if using a 4G USB modem that has to be powered by the device itself. All of the devices allow you to extend this battery life by using an external power source, which can range from 6 to 12V for the VidiU, 6-18V for the Broadcaster and 6 to 28V for the Cube. That instantly makes them compatible with a wide range of external batteries designed to power camcorders and other devices. In addition, the Cube can be powered over USB, so you can use a USB battery pack to extend its battery life. The Broadcaster is the cheapest of these devices, but that’s because it is tied in with the Livestream service: it won’t work with other video streaming services. The VidiU and Cube will work with Livestream, YouTube Live, UStream and any other service that supports the RTMP streaming protocol. The Cube also adds support for the alternative MPEG-TS video codec and point-to-point systems, where you integrate the device into a larger video setup such as a switching system. The Cube also allows you to view the live video on an iOS device on the same network, so you can preview the video as it is transmitted. The Broadcaster integrates with the companies own Livestream Studio software system, but not with other video systems. If you use the Livestream service (or don’t mind having that as your only option) the Broadcaster is a great pick. It’s simple to use, performs well and integrates well with the other services that Livestream offers, like support for broadcasting from Google Glass. But it is limited: you are locked into Livestream. Your viewers will have a possibly unfamiliar web address to remember instead of good old YouTube, UStream and the like. The VidiU offers the same features, but with wider video streaming service support including YouTube, UStream and the RTSP protocol used by most other services. Most users won’t need the extra features of the Cube (such as the support for 1080p and higher bit rate video) so the VidiU is our pick for those who want to pick up a camera, plug in and broadcast a live event to YouTube or other streaming video services over Wi-Fi. If you roam further afield, the bigger antennas and wider range of bandwidth controls might make the Cube worth the extra cost.
